title: 107_hr1621
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Act of 2001". The Arabia Mountain area in Georgia contains diverse natural, cultural, and historical resources worthy of recognition and conservation. Partnerships between public and private entities are seen as the best way to manage these resources. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve and Panola Mountain State Conservation Park protect unique ecosystems and landmarks. The Miners Creek Preserve holds evidence of early human activity. Panola Mountain, a national natural landmark in Panola Mountain State Conservation Park, is a rare granite outcrop. Miners Creek Preserve shows evidence of early human activity. Lithonia, Georgia, Arabia Mountain, and Stone Mountain display the history of granite mining. Klondike may become a National Historic District. Lithonia has 2 structures on the National Register of Historic Places. The Act aims to preserve natural, cultural, and historical resources in the area. The Act aims to recognize, preserve, promote, and interpret natural, cultural, historical, scenic, and recreational resources in the area including Arabia Mountain, Panola Mountain, Miners Creek, and other significant sites. It also aims to assist Georgia and the counties of DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry in developing and implementing a cultural, historical, and land resource management program to protect and enhance the significant resources within the heritage area. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "heritage area," "management entity," "management plan," "Secretary," and "State." SEC. 4. ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA. Establishment of Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia, consisting of land in DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties. Map available for public inspection. Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance designated as management entity. Authorities and duties of the management entity outlined. The management entity for Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia has the authority to make grants, hire staff, and enter contracts. They are responsible for developing and submitting a management plan that considers diverse interests and gives priority to preserving resources within the heritage area. The management entity for Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia has priorities outlined in the management plan, including assisting government and nonprofit organizations in resource preservation, encouraging land use policies consistent with the area's goals, conducting quarterly public meetings, submitting an annual report on accomplishments and finances, and undergoing audits. The management entity for Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia must submit an annual report detailing accomplishments, expenses, and income. They are required to make all records available for audit, including those of receiving organizations using Federal funds. Federal funds cannot be used to acquire real property. The management entity for Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia cannot use Federal funds to acquire real property, but they can use funds from other Federal laws for authorized purposes. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The management entity must develop a plan for the heritage area based on the preferred concept from the feasibility study. The plan should consider state and local plans, involve residents, agencies, and organizations, and include an inventory of resources to be preserved, restored, managed, or maintained. The management plan for the heritage area should include a list of properties to be preserved, an assessment of cultural landscapes, provisions for protection and interpretation of resources, an interpretation plan, and a program for implementation including actions by various entities and funding sources. The management plan for the heritage area should include actions by government, private organizations, and partnerships to protect resources, identification of funding sources, and evaluation of the management entity. The plan must be submitted to the Secretary for approval within 3 years, failure to do so will result in a halt of additional funding. Approval or disapproval of the management plan will be determined by the Secretary. If a management plan for the heritage area is not submitted by the specified date, additional funding under this Act will be withheld until the plan is submitted. The Secretary will approve or disapprove the management plan within 90 days of receiving it, providing recommendations for revisions if needed. After the Secretary approves a management plan for a heritage area, the management entity must periodically review the plan and submit recommendations for any necessary revisions to the Secretary for approval within 90 days. The management entity must review and submit recommendations for any revisions to the management plan to the Secretary for approval. No funds can be used to implement any proposed revisions until approved by the Secretary. SEC. 7. TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE: The Secretary may provide assistance to the heritage area for developing and implementing the management plan, prioritizing conservation and educational opportunities. 

SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS: $10,000,000 is authorized for this Act, with a maximum of $1,000,000 per fiscal year, and the Federal share of project costs not exceeding 50 percent.

SEC. 9. TERMINATION OF AUTHORITY: The authority granted by this Act will terminate after its objectives are met. The Secretary's authority to grant assistance under this Act will end on September 30, 2016.
